newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's Volga-Dnepr profit, volumes fall in Q1.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Volga-Dnepr profit, volumes fall in Q1.

text.p: Sales of Russian cargo airline AO Volga-Dnepr fell to $21.4 million in the first quarter from $23.7 million in the same period of 1996, a company spokesman said on Thursday.

Konstantin Rogov told Reuters by phone from the central Russian city of Ulyanovsk that Volga-Dnepr had carried 7,687 tonnes of cargo during first three months of this year. He could not give a comparative figure for the same period of last year.
Volga-Dnepr also reduced its flying hours to 2,077 in the first quarter of 1997 from 2,513 in January-March 1996.
"The sales and flying hours declines are to do with long-term maintenance and engine replacement for the company's two An-124 heavy freighters. We were expecting it," Rogov said.

Rogov said that the Antonov An-124s carried 6,303 tonnes of cargo between January and March. Operations with these aircraft accounted for $19.4 million of sales. "It is 15 per cent less compared to the same period of 1996," he added.
Rogov also said that the airline's An-124s were in the sky 25 percent less in the first quarter of this year.
"These planes carried aerospace industry equipment and oil exploration spare parts frequently," Rogov said.

Ulyanovsk-based Volga-Dnepr currently operates 12 cargo planes -- seven An-124s, three Ilyushin Il-76TDs, one An-12 and one An-32. It uses a Yakovlev Yak-40 jet for regular passenger flights between Ulyanovsk and Moscow.
